content.description: The subtle right-facing corner with a small roof at the top in the middle of the southwest facing section of Abraxis.  Straightforward corner climbing gives way to inventive arete pinching, steep jugs, and jamming  to the anchor. A very unique route on exceptional Navajo sandstone.
content.protection: Mostly fingers and up to #2 camalot. A nut might be advisable at the crux.
content.location: The fourth route from the right at Abraxis.

content.description:
This is a fun offwidth corner. It starts with wide hands and quickly goes to fists and wider. There are a few face holds that help out along the way.

(The route name and first ascent information were obtained from "High on Moab" by Karl Kelley.)
content.protection: #3 to #4.5 Camalots. A new #5 Camalot might also work near the finish. There's a bolted rappel anchor at the top.
content.location: Look for the right-facing wide corner about twenty feet to the left of the first pitch of Abraxas Tower.

content.description:
Start in a hand crack with stemming options out to the right. Dive into the offwidth for a couple moves then continue through a nice section of offset thin hands. The top goes to wide hands and face climbing up to a big ledge with the anchor.

The upper wide hands crack section climbs the right side of a block that isn't super confidence inspiring and there's still some loose stuff on the top ledge. Use caution especially when leading. Nothing too bad for those accustomed to desert climbing.
content.protection: (1-2) #2 cams for the start, (1) #6 for the OW, (3) #1 and (1-2) #3 for the meat of the route and (1) .4 for the top (all BD sizes). Or something like that. The crack looks wide at the bottom but there's a hand crack in the back.
content.location: Just a few minutes walk left of the main zone at Abraxas Wall but right of Shogun/Bushido. You can easily see the route from the main zone.

content.description: Long, varied, right facing corner at the far west end of Abraxis wall. Starts with short wide section then goes thin (crux) past 3 bolts. Sustained jamming/stemming will test your endurance on this crag test piece. Great climb but may be a bit sandy as it does not get done much.
content.location: Easy to see from the approach, the leftmost corner on Abraxis. Long !

climbs.name: Mary Jane Kane
climbs.fa: Joe Stern, Michelle Leber, Trevor Long, and Cody McDonald, 12/2019

content.description: Start up the crack that quickly turns into a chimney. Wiggle up the chimney then exit onto a nice ledge. From here, follow 6 bolts up the featured face.
content.protection: (1) .4 - .75, (1) 4 - 5 BD cams, and 6 quickdraws. Optional #6 cam (kind of nice, but you can get by with a #5).
content.location:
Around the corner about 20 feet to the right of the standard first pitch of Abraxas Tower. This route could also be used as an alternate first pitch to the tower.

This route faces more east than the others at Abraxas.

content.description: Short, clean, right facing corner starts as big fingers and finishes tips.

Climb a sugary pedestal, fire in a ball nut and do a boulder problem using holds out right. Establish in the shallow sub tips offset and fire in another ball nut. Move up and left clipping three bolts on your way to the anchor. Fun movement. Some holds are a bit crunchy but will clean up with more traffic.
content.location: To the right of the wide corner Sugar Cane and left of Abraxas Tower.

climbs.name: Krack Pipe
climbs.fa: Linus Platt to first anchor. Bob Scarpelli to the 2nd anchor

content.description: Starts as enjoyable double cracks with a crack switch off of a small pillar. This crack becomes OW just as the first anchor can be reached. This anchor has sprouted bolts as it used to have just a single piton. Skip this anchor and continue up the splitter OW to anchors at a nice ledge at 90'
content.protection: 1 set of Camalots to #4 to the first anchor. (2 ea) 5 & 6 to the top.
content.location: Left of a small pillar and right of Krack Kokane on the SW face.

content.description:
I don't know  the tower or route name for sure but it is a nice, casual route with short drive and a short hike

The tower barely sits off the wall and has a bird beak like summit

If you are looking at the tower from the front of the prow the route starts to the right(roadside).

Climb a varied hand crack to a large ledge.Build a belay here. Then climb easy wide crack into the chimney behind the tower. Follow chimney to the summit putting protection in a finger crack inside the chimney.
content.protection: Bring your standard rack. You will need fingers to 4 camalot sizes. There are two bolts at the top of the tower
content.location: Climb the route from the road side of the tower and rap from summit bolts to the ground on the other side of the tower.

content.description: crux is at the top just before the anchors where the crack goes o.w. and you have to make a high step out on the face.
content.protection: mostly tight hands and an optional big piece #5 or #6 camalot
content.location: vere left at the top of the trail to Abraxes Wall.  10 ft. to the right of Abraxes Left. (shares anchors with Abraxes Left) for fun you can even switch finishes to both routes about half way up the routes. also an alt start to A.R. adds a full #grade or more

content.description: Crux is at the bottom as you exit a pod to the stellar hand crack with little or no pro.
content.protection: various sizes from big fingers to 3 camalot
content.location: as you walk up the trail to the Abraxes Wall just to the left of Abraxes Right (shares anchors)
